metadata.title: Environmental friendly synthesis of silver nanomaterials from the promising Streptomyces parvus strain Al-Dhabi-91 recovered from the Saudi Arabian marine regions for antimicrobial and antioxidant properties

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Journal of Photochemistry & Photobiology, B: Biology
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/jphotobiol
Environmental friendly synthesis of silver nanomaterials from the promising Streptomyces parvus strain Al-Dhabi-91 recovered from the Saudi Arabian marine regions for antimicrobial and antioxidant properties Naif Abdullah Al-Dhabi⁎, Abdul-Kareem Mohammed Ghilan, Galal Ali Esmail, Mariadhas Valan Arasu, Veeramuthu Duraipandiyan, Karuppiah Ponmurugan Department of Botany and Microbiology, College of Sciences, King Saud University, P.O. Box 2455, Riyadh 11451, Saudi Arabia
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Marine actinobacteria Silver nitrate SEM TEM Antimicrobial activities Antioxidant properties
A B S T R A C T
The therapeutic molecules recovered from the marine biological origin are widely used for the treatment of diverse levels of infections caused by microbial pathogens. In addition, the eco-friendly preparations of nanomaterials together with the secondary metabolites' producing active microbial strains effectively suppress the spreading of the pathogenic bacteria. Considering their importance, the present study evaluated the environmental friendly synthesis of Silver nitrate nanomaterials (SNM) from the active marine Streptomyces strain AlDhabi-91 isolated from the Dammam region of Saudi Arabia. The obtained SNM was chemically characterized by various spectroscopic techniques such as UV, XRD, FTIR, SEM, TEM and EDAX; and its biological applications such as antimicrobial properties and antioxidant potential were recorded by DPPH methods. Biochemical and micromorphological studies together with the molecular techniques confirmed that the isolate Al-Dhabi-91 belonged to Streptomyces species. The characterization techniques confirmed that the UV spectrum showed maximum absorption peak at 305 nm indicating the plasmodium characteristics. SEM and TEM analyses evidenced 5–2 nm which are agglomerated, cool to form porous asymmetrical networks. Additionally, the FTIR spectrum showed maximum peak at 1194 cm−1 and 1394 cm−1, confirming the presence of aromatic CeH bending and aromatic C]C bending in the SNM. SNM exhibited prolific antibacterial activity against Gram negative pathogens, K. pneumoniae (28.33 mm) and E. coli (21.66 mm) respectively. The MIC values of SNM were significant with respect to E. faecalis (125 μg/ml), S. aureus (250 μg/ml), P. aeruginosa (125 μg/ml), K. pneumoniae (500 μg/ml) and E. coli (250 μg/ml) respectively. In addition, the antioxidant potential of the SNM was another value added importance. Especially 50 μg/ml of the nanoparticles showed 33% antioxidant potential; similarly in nitric oxide radical inhibition assay the concentration of 50 μg/ml nanoparticles showed 33% of inhibition potential. Overall, the eco-friendly synthesis of SNM from the marine Streptomyces strain Al-Dhabi-91 was an ideal active source for the treatment of infectious disease and health associated disorders.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The spreading of infectious diseases has tremendously increased due to the development of multidrug resistant microbial pathogens affecting the global human health in various aspects [1,2]. To prevent the spreading of the microbial pathogens, huge numbers of chemical molecules or target active compounds were developed to treat or kill the microbial pathogens; however, the changes in the outer surfaces of the microbial pathogens because of the development of the biofilm like mucilage substances hindered the real properties of the drugs. Microbial pathogens such as S. aureus, S. epidermidis, P. aeruginosa, M. tuberculosis and C. albicans cause serious infections associated with
immunosuppressive patients and have emerged as multidrug resistant; hence we are facing huge difficulty to eradicate them from the environment [3,4]. World Health Organization (WHO) reported that the ratio of morbidity and mortality rate of diseases occurring due to the spreading of multi drug resistant strains will lead to huge economic loss of approximately around 100 trillion US Dollars in 2050 [5]. Considering the impact of the antimicrobial resistance and importance of promising drugs, the World Health Assembly developed a global vision plan for antimicrobial resistance in 2015 [6] which was reinitiated by the United Nations General Assembly in 2016 [7]. The pharmaceutical compounds, chemicals, secondary metabolites from plants and microbial origin and other therapeutic proteins played a
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jphotobiol.2019.111529 Received 28 March 2019; Received in revised form 20 May 2019; Accepted 3 June 2019
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: naldhabi@ksu.edu.sa (N.A. Al-Dhabi).
Journal of Photochemistry & Photobiology, B: Biology 197 (2019) 111529
Available online 06 June 2019 1011-1344/ © 2019 Published by Elsevier B.V.
T
remarkable role in killing the microbial pathogens causing various infectious diseases in 21th century, and saved millions of people in the world. Reports claimed that at the end of the year 2014, approximately, 23,000 small molecules were derived from both plants and microbial origin which were tested for various biological activities [8]. Among them, 1211 active secondary metabolites recovered from plants and microbial origins were approved as drugs for the treatment of various diseases and were authenticated by the United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) [9]. The discovery and development of promising antimicrobial compounds with significant clinical applications may reduce the risk of diseases associated with multi drug resistant strains. With regard to the data of commercially available antibiotics in the market, the natural products obtained from the microbial origin, especially molecules derived from actinomycetes will prove to be an important source of active compounds for at least in the coming decades. It has been proved that the actinomycetes characterized from marine environment showed promising biological applications compared to the actinomycetes screened from the terrestrial environments. However, because of the accessibility issue to collect the samples for the isolation of active actinomycetes strains and other promising isolates, the marine environments were neglected by the researchers. Moreover, the demand for the natural products from marine actinomycetes has been increased.
Recent developments in the study of nano sized particles with unique properties have wide levels of application in bulk level production of chemicals, medical diagnostic imaging, large level production of vaccines, pharmaceutical compounds, health products, food products, optical catalysis energy, space and agricultural products respectively [10]. Nanoparticles are prepared by using various metals such as Gold (Au), Palladium (Pd), Silver (Ag), Iron (Fe), Cobalt (Co), Cadmium (Cd),Zinc (Zn), Copper (Cu) and Platinum (Pt) and oxides namely Iron (II) oxide (FeO), Zinc oxide (ZnO), Copper(II) oxide (CuO), Silver(I) oxide (Ag2O), Nickel(II) oxide (NiO), Indium oxide (In2O3), Aluminum oxide (Al2O3), Magnesium oxide (MgO), Titanium dioxide (TiO2), Cerium(IV) oxide (CeO2), Silicon dioxide (SiO2), Lanthanum oxide (La2O3), Cuprous oxide (Cu2O) and Zirconium dioxide (ZrO2) with various applications such as antioxidant, antibacterial, antifungal, antiparasitic, antiviral, antidiabetic and anti-inflammatory activities [11–19]. Among the different materials, nanoparticles prepared using Ag are used in different fields such as health care (orthopedics, cancer drugs and medical device coating machine), medical (anticancer, antiviral, antidiabetic, antifungal, immune therapy and chemotherapy) and industrial applications (preparation of cosmetics and electrical machines) [20–22]. In chemical route, materials such as glycerol, borohydride, 2-mercaptoethanol and citrate were used for the preparation of the Ag nanomaterials by different methodologies such as chemical reduction, sono-decomposition and electrochemical processing [23]. The toxicity of the nanoparticles was classified depending on the shape, size, surface chemistry and porosity. Considering the environmental hazards and toxicity, the synthesized nanoparticles by medical and physical routes have themselves limited the progress in biological applications. Hence, widespread interest is there in developing safer, cleaner, biologically compatible, non-toxic, benign, reliable, and eco-friendly greener process for the preparation of nanoparticles. Among the microorganism, the different Streptomyces species were known for the preparation of different varieties of nanoparticles preparations with multi level biological applications (Table 1) [24]. Recently, the antimicrobial actinomycetes from Dammam region of Saudi Arabia has been investigated for the promising activities against the drug resistant clinical strains. Considering the previous experiences, the present study was aimed to characterize the antimicrobial actinomycetes from the marine sediments and to develop quicker and safer method for the production of Nano crystals from silver ions for promising antibacterial activities.

sections.heading: 2.1. Chemicals and Reagents
sections.text: Silver nitrate with 99.9% purity was gifted from the department of chemistry, king Saud University. Ingredients such as glucose, sucrose and malt extract used for the cultivation medium preparations were procured from Merc, UK. Peptone, beef extract and yeast extracts were obtained from Scharlab, Spain. Sodium chloride and other salts used for the preparation of the bacteria cultivation medium were purchased from Scharlab, Spain. The water used in the experiments was treated and RO processed. The solvents and other acids used in entire process were procured from domestic suppliers. Antibiotics such as actidione, nalidixcic acid, ampicillin, streptomycin, and ketakonazole were kindly gifted from the pharmacy department, King Saud University.

sections.heading: 2.2. Different Cultivation Medium
sections.text: Alternatively, the instant growth medium such as starch casein agar medium, yeast extract and malt agar medium used for the isolation and characterization of marine actinomycetes were purchased from Himedia, India. Nutrient agar medium (peptone;0.5%, beef extract; 0.3%, yeast extract; 0.3%, Sodium Chloride; 0.5%, agar; 2.0%, pH, 7.0), Muller Hinton agar medium (beef extract; 0.2%, casein; 1.75%, starch 0.15%, agar; 2.0%, pH, 7.0), and potato dextrose agar medium (dextrose; 2.0%, potato extract; 0.4%,agar; 2.0%, pH, 6.0), were provided from Scharlab, Spain.

sections.heading: 2.3. Isolation and Screening of Marine Actinomycetes for Antimicrobial Activities
sections.text: Marine sediment samples were collected from the Saihat region of Saudi Arabia. Briefly, for collecting the sediment soil samples, 10 cm length well was made near to the brink of the sea shore and then the mud samples were collected using the sterile spatula and stored in a sterile collecting box. After that the samples were safely transported to the laboratory and stored in the cold room at 4 °C. Before starting the isolation procedures, the samples were shade dried at room temperature for 24 h and then kept in the oven at 40 °C for 24 h to eradicate the fastidious microorganisms. After the pretreatment process, the samples were dissolved in sterile cold distilled water once and serially aliquoted using serial dilution techniques [25]. After that, 100 μl of the diluted samples were transferred in to petri-plates containing the starch casein agar medium added with different concentrations of antibiotics such as actidione, nalixic acid and streptomycin. Actidione was used for the prevention of fungal growth and nalidixcic acid and streptomycin were used to prevent the unwanted growth of normal bacteria. After that, the plates were incubated at 30 °C for long time till the visible appearances of the individual actinomycetes isolates. After 14 days of incubation, the individual visible colonies were picked using sterile loop and further spread on the ISP-2 medium for purification [26]. Once the purity of the colonies was established, the isolates were named and designated as NA. Further, the purified isolates were checked for the antimicrobial properties by cross streak method. Briefly, the spore suspension of the individual isolates was streaked in the center of the MNGA plates and incubated at 30 °C for 6 days. After incubating the isolates for seven days on MNGA agar medium, freshly sub-cultured mid log phase clinical bacterial pathogens were streaked perpendicular to the actinomycetes. After incubating the plates for 17 h at 37 °C the antibacterial activities were checked. The growth pattern of the bacterial pathogens was measured using scale bar and promising actinomycetes strains with antimicrobial activities were stored in 20% glycerol at -20 °C for long term storage and in slants for routine laboratory experiments.

sections.heading: 2.4. Biochemical, Micro-Morphological and Molecular Level Characterization of Marine Actinomycetes
sections.text:
The selected marine actinomycetes were characterized by performing different biochemical tests as reported by the previous studies [27]. Briefly, growth patterns of the actinomycetes were tested at various pH, temperature and different salt concentrations. Morphological features of the actinomycetes were performed by cover slip technique in which the spore morphology of the isolates was evaluated by growing the isolates on the sterile cover slips under moisture contents. The growth pattern and pigment production capability of the isolates were determined by growing the isolates in various growing medium such as starch casein agar, modified nutrient glucose agar, potato dextrose agar, sabouraud's agar and nutrient agar medium. Micro morphological shape of the isolates was determined by performing the SEM analysis of the isolates after 7 days of cultivation. In addition, the extracellular enzyme production capability of amylase, protease and gelatinase was performed by following the standard methodology. Growth of the isolates on various carbon sources and nitrogen sources was also studied on basal medium supplemented with 0.1% carbon and nitrogen sources. Antibiotic sensitivity pattern of the isolates was profiled by disc diffusion techniques [27].
The active isolates were characterized gnomically by performing the amplification and sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene. Approximately 1.5 Kb gene sizes of the 16S rRNA gene sequences were amplified by universal forward and reverse primers and the amplified products were sequenced and checked for their similarity.

sections.heading: 2.5. Synthesis and Characterization of Nanoparticles
sections.text: For synthesis of the nanoparticles, the active marine actinomycetes were cultivated in 250 ml modified nutrient glucose broth in 500 ml conical flasks for seven days. After that the cells were separated by centrifugation at 10000 rpm for 20 min and the collected supernatant (90 ml) was mixed with 10 ml of 10 mM freshly prepared silver nitrate solution [25].The solution was mixed thoroughly and kept in an orbital shaker at room temperature for 24 h. The syntheses of the nanoparticles were confirmed by transformation of the color from light yellow to dark brown (Fig. 1). After that the solution was centrifuged at 10000 RPM for 30 min and the pellet was collected and kept in the Eppendorf. Further, the collected Eppendorfs were kept in an oven for drying the samples. The dried samples were powdered and characterized by using various analyses such as UV spectrum, FTIR, SEM, TEM, XRD and EDAX. The operation conditions for the instruments and the reagents used for processing the samples were performed by following the reported literatures.

sections.heading: 2.6. Antimicrobial Activity
sections.text: Antimicrobial activity of the nanoparticles was recorded by following the disc diffusion method. Initially, 1 mg/ml of the suspended nanoparticles was impregnated into the sterile discs and kept in sterile condition for 30 min [28]. Intermittently, sterile nutrient agar medium plates were prepared and the selected Gram positive and Gram negative strains were swabbed on top of the solid agar medium. The active microbial pathogens were prepared by proper sub-culturing of the strains in nutrient broth medium for two to three times. After swabbing the pathogens, the discs containing the nanoparticles were placed on top of the agar plates and made sure that the discs were kept safe on the plates. Alternatively, the discs with standard antibiotics were also kept as positive control and the sterile discs without any materials were also kept for the analysis. After that, the plates were kept in the incubator at 37 °C for 17 h. The zone of inhibition was measured and the experiments were repeated three times for more accuracy.

sections.heading: 2.7. Assessment of MIC Values of Nanoparticles
sections.text: MIC values of nanoparticles were categorized as the least amount of the nanoparticles suspension that purely eradicated the growth of the microbial pathogens [29]. The MIC values were ascribed by following the broth micro double dilution methods. Briefly, the freshly prepared sterile nutrient broth (100 μl) was transferred into the sterile 96 well plates. To that, 1 mg, 0.5 mg, 0.25 mg, 0.125 mg, 0.062 mg, 0.032 mg, 0.015 mg and 0.007 mg of the nanoparticles were suspended together with 5 μl of freshly prepared microbial pathogens. Alternatively, only DMSO, only nutrient broth and stand antibiotics (streptomycin) were added to the individual wells for positive control and negative control.

sections.heading: 2.8. Bacterial Strains
sections.text:
The microbial pathogens such as B. subtilis, E. faecalis (ATCC 29212), S.epidermidis (ATCC 12228), S. aureus (ATCC 29213), P. aeruginosa (ATCC 27853), K. pneumoniae (ATCC 0063) and E.coli (ATCC 25922) were procured from the American type culture collection center. The strains were delivered in the lyophilized form. For activating the strains, initially, sterile nutrient broth supplemented with extra tryptone was sterilized and the lyophilized vials were carefully broken and transferred into the growth medium. The purity of the strains was checked by performing the cross streak, quadrant streak and zigzag streak on the plates and incubated at 37 °C for 17 h. Once the purity was confirmed, single colony was transferred into the liquid culture medium and after proper growth the cells were suspended in 20% sterile glycerol and kept in the deep refrigerator for the long
AB; antibacterial activity, AC; anticancer activity, AP; Antiparasitic activity, Gupta et al. (2017) [24].
storage and for routine usages, the strains were grown in the nutrient agar slants and kept in the domestic refrigerator.

sections.heading: 2.9. DPPH Radical Scavenging Assay
sections.text:
DPPH assay for determining the antioxidant properties of the nanomaterials was performed by following the previously published methodology with slight modifications [30]. Briefly, different concentrations of the nanomaterials (10 μg, 20 μg, 30 μg, 40 μg and 50 μg) were mixed with the freshly prepared DPPH reagent in the ice cold methanol solution and after incubation for 30 min under dark condition, the change in the color of the reaction was measured at 517 nm. After that the antioxidant properties were calculated using the following formula.
= Percentage of Antioxidant activity {(absorbance at blank)–(absorbance at test)/(absorbance at blank)} X 100

sections.heading: 2.10. Nitric Oxide Scavenging Activity
sections.text:
Nitric oxide scavenging property of the nonomaterials was determined by following the method of Dharmendra Singh et al. (2012) with slight changes in the concentration of the incidents. Briefly, 100 μl of the reaction mixture containing the different concentrations of the nanomaterials together with the 5 mM buffer (10mM sodium nitroprusside and phosphate buffer) were taken and incubated at 20 °C for
2 h; after that, 1000 μl of Griess reagent were transferred to the reaction mixture and the changes in the color reactions were measured at 550 nm. After that the antioxidant properties were calculated using the following formula.
= Percentage of Antioxidant activity {(absorbance at blank)–(absorbance at test)/(absorbance at blank)} X 100

sections.heading: 2.11. Statistical Analysis
sections.text: For statistical analysis, the results were analyzed for mean, standard deviation and standard error using the Microsoft excel 2016 version.

sections.heading: 3.1. Isolation and Screening of Marine Actinomycetes for Antimicrobial Activities
sections.text:
Marine actinobacteria are known for active extracellular compounds with various biological activities. Especially, the marine actinobacteria are known for inhibiting the growth of the infectious disease causing Gram positive and Gram negative clinical microbes. Considering the importance of the actinobacteria from the marine origin, the present study was intended to cultivate the active marine actinobacteria from the Dammam coastal region of Saudi Arabia. Isolation experiments were performed using the SCA agar medium
guided to select 50 suspected actinobateria and the selections were carried out based on their morphology, diffusible pigment production capability and the spore forming capacity. The suspected actinobacteria strains were labeled as Al-Dhabi-50 to Al-Dhabi-101 and the strains' purity was confirmed by growing on ISP-2 medium. Primary screening of the actinobacteria against the bacterial pathogens authenticated that the strains such as Al-Dhabi-91, Al-Dhabi-97, and Al-Dhabi-101, were significantly active (Fig. 2). Among them, the strain Al-Dhabi-91 showed promising activity towards the Gram positive and Gram negative clinical strains. Especially, the isolate completely suppressed the growth of the Gram positive bacteria and moderately inhibited the Gram negative bacteria. Further, the strain Al-Dhabi-91 was characterized based on its micro morphological, biochemical and molecular characteristics.

sections.heading: 3.2. Biochemical, Micro-Morphological and Molecular Level Characterization of Marine Actinomycetes
sections.text: The isolate Al-Dhabi-91 expressed promising antibacterial activities towards the tested infectious disease causing pathogens. Micro-morphological studies conducted using SEM instrument evidenced that the isolate was roughly 0.9 μm and 1.4 μm in its cross section and the length respectively; additionally, the cells were attached very tightly with each other. The isolate was Gram positive and grew well under aerobic and micro aerobic conditions. Comparatively the rate of growth on the SCA broth and MNG broth was poor and took approximately seven to ten days for complete growth. The appearance of the mycelia cells on the liquid medium was small ball size with brownish red color on the cell surfaces. The growth pattern of the isolate on SCA, SDA, PDA, MNGA, NA and CA media was good with cherry red color aerial mycelia, and rough light red color vegetative mycelia on the top of the agar medium. The isolate was able to secrete dark red soluble pigment on the cultivation media and spores were red in color. The wide level growth pattern of the isolate at 20 °C to 37 °C was interesting and was completely killed at 45 °C indicating that the isolate was not a thermophilic bacterium. In addition, the survival rates of the isolate on different buffering conditions from 6 to 8 and tolerance levels of different proportion of NaCl from 2 to 5 percentages revealed its wide level adaptability nature. The production ability of extracellular enzymes such as protease, amylase, and gelatinase was interesting apart from the antimicrobial production capacity. Specifically, the carbohydrate (glucose, sucrose, fructose, maltose, fructose and galactose) assimilation pattern and nitrogen (arginine, histidine, cysteine, valine, phenylalanine, threonine, serine, asparagine and alanine) source utilization capability (Table 2) were promising. The resistant pattern towards different antibiotics such as streptomycin and kanamycin confirmed that the isolate belonged to Streptomyces species. Further, the 16S rRNA gene amplification and sequencing results proved that the isolate showed 100% sequence similarity towards the Streptomyces species and the sequenced nucleotide base pairs (1348) were deposited in the NCBI database under the accession number MH201372.1. The 16S rRNA gene sequence of the isolate revealed 2542 query coverage and 100% identity with E value of 0.0 towards the deposited 16S rRNA gene sequences from the other Streptomyces species. The novel antibacterial strain Al-Dhabi-91 documented 99.78 percentage of sequence similarity with the Streptomyces parvus strain 3151 (Fig. 3). Overall, the biochemical and molecular level identification experiments confirmed that the strain AlDhabi-91 belonged to the genus Streptomyces.

sections.heading: 3.3. Eco-Friendly Green Synthesis of Nanoparticles and Spectral Characterization
sections.text:
For the rapid synthesis of nanoparticels, different concentrations of aqueous AgNO3 solution (1 mM, 4 mM, 6 mM, 8 mM and 10 mM) were mixed with cell free washed water free extract. The creation of the nonmaterials was visually confirmed with the rapid changes of the
liquid color from colorless to cherry red. Wave length scanning UV spectrum showed maximum absorption peak at 330 nm indicating the plasmodium characteristics of the material (Fig. 4). Additionally, the FTIR spectrum of the AgNO3 and the obtained nanoparticles showed some variations in the band pattern especially the nanoparticles were spotted at 1194 cm−1 and 1394 cm−1, confirming the presence of aromatic CeH bonding and aromatic C]C bonding in the materials; however similar spot was not obtained in the AgNO3 solution. XRD studies (diffraction peaks 111, 200, 220, 222, 311, and 400 and peak width of 0.8, 0.5, 0.7, 0.9, 0.03 and 1.1 respectively) proved that the shapes and sizes of the nanoparticels were crystalline and rich lattice fringes and ranged from 9.7 nm to 17.25 nm respectively. SEM, EDAX and TEM results evidenced that the nanoparticle was 5–2 nm in its size, looked agglomerate on its outer surfaces and 10 to 13 nm in its international chemical molecular structure (Figs. 5, 6). Overall, the characterization techniques concluded that the obtained materials shared authenticated results belonging to nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 3.4. In vitro Antimicrobial Potentials of Nanoparticles
3.4.1. Antimicrobial Potentials of Nanoparticles by Agar Well Method
sections.text:
The antimicrobial activities of the suspension of silver nanoparticles were determined by cup plate method. The zone of inhibition of the nanoparticles is displayed in Table 1. Results attributed that the nanoparticles showed positive response towards the Gram positive bacteria such as S. aureus, S. epidermidi, E. faecalis and B. subtilis with the inhibition zone ranging 23, 13.33, 16.33 and 21.66 mm respectively (Fig. 7). Among the Gram negative pathogens, K. pneumoniae
(28.33 mm) and E. coli (21.66) showed highest level of inhibition zone with the nanoparticles. All the tested clinical pathogens showed positive response towards the standard antibiotic streptomycin.

sections.heading: 3.4.2. Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (MIC) of Silver Nanomaterials
sections.text:
Results clearly indicated that the nanoparticle from isolate Al-
Dhabi-91 revealed MIC values from 125 μg/ml to 250 μg/ml, for the Gram positive bacteria such as E. faecalis (125 μg/ml) and S. aureus (250 μg/ml) respectively (Table 3). The MIC values of Gram negative bacteria were noted as P. aeruginosa (125 μg/ml), K. pneumoniae (500 μg/ml) and E. coli (250 μg/ml) respectively. The MIC values of the standard antibiotics were comparable.

sections.heading: 3.5. In-vitro Antioxidant Activities of Silver Nanomaterials
sections.text: The in-vitro antioxidant potentials of the nanoparticles are shown in the Fig. 3. Results confirmed that the antioxidant potentials of the nanoparticles increased with increasing concentration (Fig. 8A). Especially 50 μg/ml of the nanoparticles showed 33% antioxidant potentials; similarly in nitric oxide radical inhibition assay the concentration of 50 μg/ml, nanoparticles showed 33% of inhibition potentials (Fig. 8B). The present study confirmed that the expression of the antioxidant potentials might be linked with the extracellular components of the actinobacteria with regards to the phenolic compounds attachments.

sections.heading: 4. Discussion
sections.text:
In the present study, primary screening revealed that the active
components produced by the isolates were active in the liquid state. The present results concluded that the killing properties of the actinomycetes were because of the secretion of secondary metabolites. It is well known that most of the promising molecules are excreted from the
extracellular portion of the biological samples [31]. The promising compounds from actinobacteria belonged to various chemical classes such as glycopeptides, macrolides, tetracyclines, aminoglycosides, polyketides, actionomycins, peptides, benzoxazolophenanthridines, macrolides,octaketides, anthracyclines, polyesters, nucleosides, betalactams and polyenes respectively [32,33].
Biochemical, physiological, and morphological properties of the selected marine actinomycetes showed similarity towards the Streptomyces species and 16S rRNA gene sequencing analysis authenticated that the isolate showed identity towards Streptomyces species. The actinomycetes isolates grew well at 30 °C and 37o C, but did not grow at 45 °C. Substrate mycelia were well-branched [34]. Johnson et al. (2001) reported that the important characteristics of Streptomyces were aerial mycelium with spore-mass color, and pigmentation of substrate mycelium [35]. Xu et al. [36] isolated novel actinomycete strain YIM 31724 T from the marine samples of China. The genus Streptomyces is well defined as a result of the application of chemotaxonomic, molecular systematic and numerical phenotypic methods [37–39].
Silver nanoparticles synthesized by eco-friendly method were proved by techniques such as UV, FTIR, SEM, TEM, EDAX and XRD. The characterization techniques eventually authenticated that the materials were nano in their appearances and their surface characteristics. For additional evidence the produced materials were subjected to wavelength scanning and it confirmed that the maximum absorption was at 230 nm clearly proving that the synthesized materials were nanoparticles. Additionally, the SEM and TEM studies clearly authenticated the size of the silver nanoparticles. Fig. 5(a-f) shows that the result consists of a great quantity of cluster-like nanocrystals were grown at narrow size distribution. However, the SEM image represents that an individual Ag nanocrystal which is directed, as good crystallinity and rich lattice fringes which is seeming that have regular hexagonal shape cluster like nanocrystals route it consists of 5–2 nm which are agglomerated, cool to form porous asymmetrical networks, though the synthesized nanoparticles consist of mono-disperse nanoparticles, as detected in the TEM images respectively [40]. Morphological shape and size of the synthesized AgNPs was observed using SEM images as in Fig. 5(b-c), spherical nanoparticles with round edges was observed the orientation plane of crystals [41]. The size of the nanoparticle obtained
in were agreed with the SEM results. The MIC values were determined by broth micro dilution technique, because it was predicted that the studied nanomaterials were completely dissolved in the solution and attacked the bacterial cells from further growth. It was predicted that the nanoparticles altered the outer cellular membrane and entered into the cells. Also, the activities of internal protein and DNA molecules might have been altered there by the clinical pathogens would have been killed. In coincides with the present study, recently, silver nanomaterials were prepared eco-firnely using the extracellular supernatant of Streptomyces sp. recovered from acid forest soil regions showed activity against the clinically serious pathogens such as P. aeruginosa and K. pneumoniae [42]. Kim et al. (2007) concluded that the green synthesis of silver nanoparticles obtained from the promising S. rocheii exhibited comparatively better activity against pathogens such as K. pneumoniae, E. coli and B. subtilis respectively [43]. Similarly, nanoparticles synthesiszed environmental friendly from Streptomyces sp. JAR1 inhibited the Gram positive bacteria at lower concentrations [44] Recently Kumar et al. [40] isolated Streptomyces sp. from the forest soil samples, and used as the material for the synthesis of silver nanoparticles. The nanoparticles revealed good suppressive activity towards E. aerogenes and S. flexneri [41]. Kaviya et al. [42] suggested that the activity of silver nanoparticles to various microbial pathogens were because of the colloidal nature of silver ions. Similarly, Augustine et al. [43] and Panáček et al. [44] authenticated the antimicrobial properties of the silver nanoparticles against Gram positive and Gram negative microbial pathogens and found that it was because of the colloidal nature and small size of the nanoparticles. The produced silver nanoparticles were attracted by the cell wall because of the charges of the cell wall and silver ions and further permeated inside the cells resulting in cell death [45]. Subashini et al. [46] isolated Streptomyces from fertile mud and directed for the synthesis of silver nanoparticles.
The MIC values of the nanoparticles produced by the isolateAlDhabi-89 to the drug resistant clinical pathogens were interesting. Especially the nanoparticles documented variable levels of MIC values. It is interesting that the actinomycetes isolates obtained from the marine region of Dammam, Saihat, AL Khobar, Dhahran and Half Moon Bay exhibited good antimicrobial activities. The results were comparable with the report of the other researchers. Mahroop and Ahmed [47] identified Micromonospora species (KU 867645) from Tuticorin which showed antimicrobial activity against the clinical pathogens; in addition the silver nanoparticles produced from the extracellular products effectively showed better activity against the clinical multidrug-resistant pathogens from the hospital. Silver nanoparticles obtained from the promising Streptomyces coelicoflavus KS-3 recorded significant anticancer activity against various cell lines such as human bronchial epithelial cells, lung squamous cell carcinoma cells and lung adenocarcinoma cells [48]. Iniyan et al. [49] reported that the nanoparticles obtained from the Streptomyces exfoliatus ICN25 exhibited increased antimicrobial activity against methicillin-resistant P. aeruginosa, S.
aureus, E. coli and at K. pneumonia 1 μg/mL concentrations [49]. It was ascribed that the Gram positive clinical pathogens were not vulnerable to the nanomaterials because of the chemical structure of the peptidoglycan layer; however in the present study both isolates recorded interesting activity to prevent the spreading of pathogenic strains [50–54].

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text:
In this study, the extracellular metabolites produced from the marine Streptomyces sp. Al-Dhabi-91 was evaluated for effective ecofriendly synthesis of SNM by green chemistry approach. The development of SNM was noted by alterations in the color changes from colorless to light brown color further by UV spectroscopy. Maximum absorption peak at 305 nm indicated the plasmodium characteristics of the nanomaterials. The characterization of the nanomaterials proved that the formed SNM were stable and crystalline in nature. Further, the nanomaterials showed better antibacterial activity with comparable MIC values against clinically important pathogens such as E. faecalis (125 μg/ml), S. aureus (250 μg/ml), P. aeruginosa (125 μg/ml), K. pneumoniae (500 μg/ml) and E. coli (250 μg/ml) respectively. Additionally the antioxidant potentials of the nanmaterials was a value added advantages. Overall, the process followed for the preparation of eco-friendly synthesis SNM from the Streptomyces sp. Al-Dhabi-91 is applicable in the field of nanomedicine for the killing of pathogenic disease causing bacteria. Overall, the eco-friendly synthesis of SNM from the marine actinobacterium Streptomyces strain Al-Dhabi-91 is a promising source for the drug development program.
A: 100 μm; B:10 μm; C:5 μm; D:2 μm; E:1 μm; F:0.5 μm.

sections.heading: Acknowledgement
sections.text: The authors would like to extend their sincere appreciation to the Deanship of Scientific Research at King Saud University for the funding of this research through the Research Group Project No. RG-1440-107.

referenceMentions.context: The spreading of infectious diseases has tremendously increased due to the development of multidrug resistant microbial pathogens affecting the global human health in various aspects [1,2].

World Health Organization (WHO) reported that the ratio of morbidity and mortality rate of diseases occurring due to the spreading of multi drug resistant strains will lead to huge economic loss of approximately around 100 trillion US Dollars in 2050 [5].

Considering the impact of the antimicrobial resistance and importance of promising drugs, the World Health Assembly developed a global vision plan for antimicrobial resistance in 2015 [6] which was reinitiated by the United Nations General Assembly in 2016 [7].

metadata.abstractText: The therapeutic molecules recovered from the marine biological origin are widely used for the treatment of diverse levels of infections caused by microbial pathogens. In addition, the eco-friendly preparations of nanomaterials together with the secondary metabolites' producing active microbial strains effectively suppress the spreading of the pathogenic bacteria. Considering their importance, the present study evaluated the environmental friendly synthesis of Silver nitrate nanomaterials (SNM) from the active marine Streptomyces strain AlDhabi-91 isolated from the Dammam region of Saudi Arabia. The obtained SNM was chemically characterized by various spectroscopic techniques such as UV, XRD, FTIR, SEM, TEM and EDAX; and its biological applications such as antimicrobial properties and antioxidant potential were recorded by DPPH methods. Biochemical and micromorphological studies together with the molecular techniques confirmed that the isolate Al-Dhabi-91 belonged to Streptomyces species. The characterization techniques confirmed that the UV spectrum showed maximum absorption peak at 305 nm indicating the plasmodium characteristics. SEM and TEM analyses evidenced 5–2 nm which are agglomerated, cool to form porous asymmetrical networks. Additionally, the FTIR spectrum showed maximum peak at 1194 cm−1 and 1394 cm−1, confirming the presence of aromatic CeH bending and aromatic C]C bending in the SNM. SNM exhibited prolific antibacterial activity against Gram negative pathogens, K. pneumoniae (28.33 mm) and E. coli (21.66 mm) respectively. The MIC values of SNM were significant with respect to E. faecalis (125 μg/ml), S. aureus (250 μg/ml), P. aeruginosa (125 μg/ml), K. pneumoniae (500 μg/ml) and E. coli (250 μg/ml) respectively. In addition, the antioxidant potential of the SNM was another value added importance. Especially 50 μg/ml of the nanoparticles showed 33% antioxidant potential; similarly in nitric oxide radical inhibition assay the concentration of 50 μg/ml nanoparticles showed 33% of inhibition potential. Overall, the eco-friendly synthesis of SNM from the marine Streptomyces strain Al-Dhabi-91 was an ideal active source for the treatment of infectious disease and health associated disorders.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
